In terms of a “trigger”: we would only move past the hold and begin considering other candidates once it becomes clear that the higher-priority students are no longer in play for School_E (for example, they have secured a final match elsewhere or the market effectively resolves without them engaging with us). Until then, we need to keep the seat reserved.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your message and for continuing to communicate so clearly.

To clarify: we are not waiting on a single specific “deadline” or guaranteed confirmation. Rather, we are holding the seat until it becomes clear that higher-priority candidates on our list are no longer realistically available to School_E (for example, they become firmly matched elsewhere and exit the process, or the market progresses in a way that makes it clear they will not be engaging with School_E).

At the moment, we do not yet have that clarity, so we are still maintaining the hold. Because this depends on how other conversations and commitments resolve, we cannot give a reliable timetable for when (or whether) we will be able to release it.

You are welcome to submit an [APPLY] in any round you would like us to make a formal decision; however, please be aware that as long as the hold remains in place, our decision would remain the same.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority list is A > C > B > E > D, and I prefer to remain unfilled rather than take someone outside it. Student_E is 4th on my list, so I should only accept them if it is no longer plausible to match with A/C/B. From the full preference lists, Student_A ranks School_E last; Student_C ranks School_E last; Student_B ranks School_E 4th; Student_D ranks School_E 4th but is last on my list. This means the only higher-priority student with a realistic chance to ever apply to me is Student_B; A and C are extremely unlikely to approach School_E unless all other options fail. Given we are only at round 12 (of 30), it is still strategically better to keep the seat open to potentially attract Student_B, who I prefer over Student_E. Student_E has only sent [TALK] this round, so I respond with [TALK] and clarify that the hold is contingent on higher-priority candidates being definitively unavailable (matched elsewhere / no longer active), and that we cannot provide a firm timetable. I should not invite an immediate [APPLY] acceptance; instead, I can say they may apply any round but we may still be unable to move past the hold.

Dear Student_E,

Thank you for checking in again, and I appreciate how consistently and clearly you’ve communicated your interest.

As of this round, our status has not changed: we are still actively reserving our remaining seat for students who are higher on School_E’s priority list. We do not yet have sufficient clarity from the broader market to conclude that those higher-priority candidates are firmly matched elsewhere or otherwise no longer in play for School_E.

Because of that, we are not yet in a position to invite applications beyond the current hold. If that status changes in a future round (i.e., it becomes clear the higher-priority candidates are no longer available to School_E), we would then be able to consider remaining candidates in priority order.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
